description:
MiniSQL is a Domain-Specific Language (DSL) + database engine that simplifies the SQL language in a replicated manner.
This means it's a language very similar to the original SQL but supports only the commands CREATE DATABASE, CREATE TABLE, INSERT, SELECT and DELETE along with their respective actions.
For a complete explanation of syntax, documentation, and usage, refer to the GitHub repository.

This web platform allows users to easily and intuitively download audio from YouTube videos in MP3 and WAV formats. The ytdl-core library was utilized to fetch the video's bitstream. For the conversion to MP3 and WAV formats, fluent-ffmpeg was integrated, a library that leverages the FFMPEG tool for the task.
Given that FFMPEG needs to be present on the server, I opted to dockerize the backend. This ensures the tool is available, facilitating hassle-free audio conversion.

This app allows consumption of some of the endpoints provided by the Insurance API.
Once the admin user is logged in, he/she can view all insured with filtering options and see their respective details in a simple and comprehensive manner.
App built using the MVVM (Model-View-ViewModel) design pattern.

This system consists of a web visual interface consuming the Insurance API. Other uses of the API in other projects are described there.
Once the admin user is logged in, he/she can utilize all functions available in the API, including viewing all clients, adding, removing, and modifying them individually, bulk importing via an Excel file, and exporting records in PDF or Excel format. It should be noted that the interface is not 100% responsive since there's a specific mobile app for phone views. However, it adapts correctly to any PC or tablet screen.

This API allows all types of queries to the client database of an insurance company.
Access is restricted only to admin users, meaning the owners of the insurance company or office. Therefore, for security reasons, the API does not have endpoints that allow the insertion of admin users into the system.
Beyond CRUD operations, it allows for bulk import of insured data from an Excel file, complying with the format specified here, simplifying the data loading process.
It also enables the generation of reports, in both PDF and XLSX formats, from the export of the database records.
This project is part of a set of related projects, which includes a frontend web interface and an Android mobile application, providing a comprehensive solution and naturally consuming from this API.
API built using the MVC (Model-View-Controller) design pattern.

Both the frontend and backend sections are located in the GitHub root directory.
The system has two user roles: admin role and client role.
A client user can see the company's car gallery and rent the one they wish after registering and logging into the system. They also have a section to view their rental history with the option to cancel those that are active.
An admin user can confirm or deny the client's payment from their interface to validate or respectively cancel the rental.
The entire project is dockerized. The database must be run on Docker exclusively for user convenience.
Then, there's the option to run the frontend and backend with Node and Java respectively if those interpreters are installed. Otherwise, both can run in isolated containers.
API built using the MVC (Model-View-Controller) design pattern.
A minimalist portfolio, offering a seamless showcase of my skills, projects, and personal journey. Optimized for intuitive and easy navigation.

Both the backend and frontend sections are located in different directories but in the same uploaded GitHub repository.
The system has two user roles: administrator role and client role. However, any person without registering will also be able to view the page content.
An unregistered user can see all the products available in the store, with filtering options.
A logged-in client user can see all available store products and also use a favorites list, adding the items they are most interested in and viewing them with a single click.
An administrator user can add clothes and/or perfumes to the web catalog, remove them or modify them.
API built using the MVC (Model-View-Controller) design pattern.

This game does not have any login or registration, as it was delivered as the final project for one of the early courses in the program.
In the settings section, users can set their username for gameplay.
It also has a messaging application, where users can chat with another computer running the program by entering its IP address. This messaging feature was developed because one of the final project requirements was to use sockets in JAVA. The original idea was to make an online version of the 'truco' game, but due to time constraints, we improvised by creating a chat.

This project was completed for the final exam of the Computer Networks course.
The goal was to develop a protocol similar to the workings of the File Transfer Protocol to achieve a comprehensive understanding.
It has implemented a small number of commands that primarily allow file transfer requests, list files in a directory, and change directories on the server.
